description:
Apiospora aurea is a species of fungus that belongs to the phylum Ascomycota. It is a saprobic organism, meaning it derives its nutrients from decomposing organic matter. Apiospora aurea is known to be found in various parts of the world, including Europe and North America, where it commonly grows on decaying wood and plant material.

The fungus produces small, golden-yellow to orange-yellow, spherical or slightly elongated fruiting bodies called perithecia, which are the structures that contain the sexual spores. These perithecia typically measure around 0.5-1 mm in diameter and are often clustered together. The spores produced within the perithecia are called ascospores, and they are forcibly discharged from the fruiting bodies to aid in the dispersal of the fungus.

Apiospora aurea is classified as a member of the order Xylariales, which is known for its diverse group of saprobic fungi that play an important role in the decomposition of woody plant material. The specific epithet "aurea" refers to the golden-yellow color of the fungal fruiting bodies.
